\begin{itemize}
\item This quiz tests whether you are spending sufficient time on the assigned reading. If you fail, you will lose 2 of the 10 reading points allocated towards your final grade.
\item Passing the quiz requires 6 points.  
\item Enter all requested information on the top of this page.
\item You may \textit{not} use your books, notes, etc.
\item Do not write in the table to the right.
\end{itemize}

\vqword{Problem}

\gradetable[v]%[pages]  % Use [pages] to have grading table by page instead of question

\begin{questions}
\addpoints
\question{Tick the correct answer:} 
\begin{parts}

\part[1] Which of the following philosophers is NOT mentioned in ch.2:
\begin{checkboxes}
\choice Aristotle 
\choice Socrates
\end{checkboxes}


\part[1] Ch.2 is concerned with the relationship between time and change
\begin{checkboxes}
\choice True
\choice False
\end{checkboxes}

\part[1] The existence of temporal vacua would provide support for which of the following views? 
\begin{checkboxes}
\choice Absolutism
\choice Relationalism
\end{checkboxes}



\part[1] The fact that time cannot speed up or slow down is evidence for which claim? 
\begin{checkboxes}
\choice Time is distinct from change.
\choice Time is not distinct from change. 
\end{checkboxes}

\part[1] One argument for the existence of temporal vacua is
\begin{checkboxes}
\choice The experience argument
\choice The measure argument
\choice Everything has a reason 
\choice None of the above
\end{checkboxes}
\end{parts}
\newpage
\question[5] Answer ONE of the following questions. Write 3--5 sentences: 
\begin{itemize}
\item Why, according to ch.2, does it not make sense to think of time speeding up or slowing down? 
\item Summarize the experience argument
\item Summarize the measure argument
\item Summarize the `everything has a reason' argument.
\end{itemize} 

\vspace{3.5in}




\end{questions}
